transcription.text: >> Thanks for being here and thanks for staying despite the typhoon.
I lead a project called the open money initiative.
Today we're going to leave behind a little bit for this talk for 20 minutes.
These very technical talk, these very technical keywords.
We're going to go back to basics to why this technology matters and how do we help people
and the most.
I want to introduce you to Lorena who is a baker, 48-year-old.
She's from Venezuela, the country where I'm from.
She, in order to get her money out and in order to herself escape from poverty, scarcity,
she needed to convert her savings into US dollars, which she did by using the black
markets back when it was illegal and dangerous.
After that, she needed to fall the bills into her hair so she could cross the border safely
because the border between Colombia and Venezuela is very dangerous.
The guards are very corrupt and they're just looking for any way to make income because
the guards are as anyone in the way living through a very difficult situation of economic
collapse and hyperinflation, as you may know.
At the Open Money Initiative, we research how people use money in close economies and
collapsing monetary systems.
This year, we focused on my home country, Venezuela, and we did some, what people call
"designed research".
We follow, we borrow this, we're approached from IDEO, one of our partners and collaborators.
We try to go to the places where these people live, we observe them, we set up different
research methods to collect qualitative data that tells us a lot about why people do what
they do, how people do what they do, and we go beyond the statistics of this million
percent inflation or whatever and really look at the human experience of what that is like.
You can think of it as a process of search more than research.
We are searching for inspiration, for products that could help these people be more resilient
and better prepared for calamity.
Our methods vary depending on what our goals are.
This year, for this project, we did ethnographic interviews, which means we sit down with
people, we talk with them for about two hours, and we try to get them to open up.
Money is a very difficult topic subject to get people to open up about.
We present them with some emotional cards and we try to get them to get acquainted with
us and establish some report.
We did some interviews in person in Columbia and we did some interviews remotely because
we unfortunately couldn't enter Venezuela for this time around.
It's a long story.
We also did a diary studies.
We wanted to know what people's experience was like day to day and we followed people
during the week and these people were located in Venezuela.
Thankfully, what's at works and it's possible to run a study still like this.
We did what we call displacements, which are ways that we could tell people, hey, for
example, here's some Bitcoin, use it to buy something and tell us what you did.
Of course, this is not to really get at the ways that people would be using Bitcoin ordinarily
because it's a very rough intervention.
It's more about getting to know what is difficult about these technologies and how do we overcome
that and get inspiration for that.
The process in the end looks a lot like this.
We have a lot of post-its from all the different interviews.
We try to sort them, organize them, and try to depict patterns in the data.
I'm going to run quickly because this presentation is supposed to be four to five minutes,
but I'm going to try to run quickly through the main themes where we organized our research
insight on.
First is about confidence.
In Venezuela, networks of people have replaced the roles of companies and institutions, which
means the state and the companies are no longer operating or they are diminishing their
way that they are operating.
What is the fallback in those cases is you go and trust your neighbors or you trust your
extended family or you go to the internet and go to websites that replace the need or replace
that they use that you have for traditional institutions.
For example, instead of exchanging money by going to a bank, the way you do it is you
go to Facebook or Instagram and search for places that offer this informal service of
remaining and transferring money abroad.
Here we see an example of this is a money changer who lives in Nédéin and every day he prepares
these images and sends them to his entire network because he works as a money changer.
One of the few ways you can earn money in foreign currency in Venezuela is by doing currency
exchange.
His sister in this case lives in Venezuela and she collaborates with him so they can get
money moving from one country to another.
By the way, it does not involve cryptocurrency in any way.
This is another example.
People use the feature of WhatsApp that is like Instagram stories to advertise their
services and sending and receiving money.
The thing is if you are in a normal country like Japan, the US, UK, you can send money
by going to a bank and saying, "I want to wire money to this bank."
The corresponding banking system is complicated.
Clunky has a lot of fees, whatever, but it works.
In Venezuela, this system does not work because the government does not allow banks to talk
to banks outside.
We have had these sort of capital controls for about 20 years.
The way that you do it is if you want to convert your money to money abroad, you have
to send someone that has a bank account in the other country and you need to send him
money first and then receive the money on the other side.
This, of course, is prone to scams and abuse, which we will see.
This leads me to the second one.
Every transaction is forced to feel like a drug deal.
Everything is kind of underground.
Here I am trying to send money to a foundation in Venezuela and I am in Colombia and in
this booth.
This guy is telling me, "Hey, you have to WhatsApp this number and he will let you know
when the transaction is cleared."
Everything is kind of like doing drug deals.
Doing doing very shady feels that you have to trust somebody and there's a lot of scams.
Something that we found that was kind of unexpected, at least for me, was that despite
scarcity and economic collapse, some people are thriving.
You would think Venezuela is a country that has the importance so quickly that everyone
must be suffering.
In fact, hyperinflation has made some millionaires because if you are well connected like this
guy we talked to, Guillermo, he was able to get a loan issued in Bolivars and he bought
an apartment in New York City with that loan.
Since the loan was in Bolivars, he was able to repay it the next year.
There was a million-dollar loan and he paid it with $20,000 because the value of loan
just collapsed.
There's people that can gain this system and can get huge benefits.
That tells you that the economic system that Venezuela is trying to impose actually elevates
the level of self-inequality rather than making things more equal, which is really terrible.
We also see people trying to take advantage of others by scams, like the pyramid scheme
type things where cryptocurrency is sometimes used because it's the easiest way to move
money in the shadow banking system.
These people tell us that they don't see themselves as cameras, they just see themselves as financial
innovators, but if you look at the way they are operating, it's probably not sustainable.
The most vulnerable, he interviewed this six-year-old lady who was about to fall for one of these
scams.
It's very common that the people that don't know or that are not very financial literate
are falling for these things.
This happens in a situation of uncertainty and economic collapse when people waste or earn
money are diminished.
We're going to go to resilient.
Venezuelans have to endure constant swings between modern and primitive existences.
Sometimes you are having a perfectly normal afternoon or a normal day.
You go to work, you have electricity, you have internet.
It looks like the same things are normal, but then it's like the typhoon that's going to
hit, that hopefully will not hit.
Everything might lose power, we might lose internet.
These things happen so frequently that it's impossible to plan in advance.
Sometimes if you have to take your kid to daycare and then daycare doesn't have electricity
and they can take care of him for you, then you have to stay at home and then you can
go to work.
These things pile on top of each other and make a domino effect.
This is something that's very important to take into account when you're designing for
a product or products for people like this.
And of course it makes it very challenging.
Income from the informal economy often eclipses space the salaries.
We interviewed this career woman who is a professor at the University, tenure professor
at a university, and she spends her days doing tasks that are way below her level of ability
because she makes more money doing that than at her job as a university professor for example.
This is not the only time that we've encountered this.
We also talk to people who work as drivers, doctors who have also stuck to drivers.
If you notice it's very similar to what happened in Cuba.
Any profession or any occupation that interfaces with the outside world that is able to earn
hard currency is then valued more and you can earn more money in it.
And then you do your job as part of your role in society, if you're a teacher, if you're
a doctor, but you also have to have enough for a family to eat.
So you need to take on these two jobs.
Leaving Venezuela is going from a sinking ship to a life of a few provisions.
This we got, especially because we focused in Colombia.
And we noticed that there was a lot of migrants coming, which spoke well with a lot of migrants.
People have this expectation that when they leave Venezuela everything will be all right.
But when they find themselves in a new country, they don't have their support systems.
And as I mentioned, the institutions probably don't work for them because maybe they don't
have papers.
Maybe they can't get a bank account.
So this is something that I could take into account.
And then lastly, this is my favorite category, open.
Nobody wants the Bolivar, but it's necessary to survive.
So, as you can see, the Bolivar is only useful now to make home decorations and things like
these.
And they're beautiful.
But it's also a sign of the tragedy that's occurring, right?
And then you might think, oh, no one's using the Bolivar, like, because who would use such
a worthless currency?
But in fact, it is the currency that is most widely distributed.
And then if that's what people have to trade, it will take a long time for it to be replaced
by something a lot more convenient, like, say, die or say the US dollar in cash.
Even though it's making inroads, especially US dollar in cash or making big inroads in
Venezuela, it takes a long time for local currencies to be replaced.
When someone is selling a product, they have the power to choose how they get paid.
They have that, like, asymmetry of power, right?
So, for example, we spoke with this guy who was trying to find medicine for his mom.
And he didn't have Zell, which is an interbank transfer platform in the United States.
It's very popular in Venezuela because there are still many people who have, not many, many,
but there's thousands of people who have bank accounts in the US and have registered for
Zell.
So, this guy didn't have access to that.
And the medicine that he was supposed to purchase required that.
The guy who sold the medicine was like, okay, you will give me the money in Zell or else I won't sell you the medicine,
which is kind of terrible for him, but eventually he was able to find an uncle that could lend his account to him.
So, you know, just keep, like, those things in mind.
It's just mind blowing, right?
When you live in Venezuela, there's no good way to save.
There's no ideal way to save.
What we noticed was we spoke with three different people that have different approaches,
but you'll notice that none of these approaches are actually ideal.
So, we spoke with one very bright student who got into mind in Bitcoin and saved her money in Bitcoin.
Of course, it's volatile, but she preferred it to having US dollars because she could pull it out at any time.
Because it turns out that local Bitcoins is the most liquid, the most convenient way to convert from a foreign currency,
if you consider Bitcoin a foreign currency, to bother you.
So, if you keep your money there, in a matter of five minutes, you can get the money in your bank account and you can pay for things,
which is really amazing.
Then there's people that save money in dollars in cash, but then it is unsafe.
So, if you have someone that can keep the money for you, especially if you live in an area where it's more unsafe,
then you try to keep the money there.
And then we are starting to see digital money platforms being used.
So, there's a company called RTM, an uphold that are enabling these kinds of services.
They're not using cryptocurrency quite yet, and some of these are still in its infancy.
They have to become better at being mobile first and so on.
And so, the government actually blocked RTM from operating, but it's a very simple block to bypass.
So, people need to have VPNs to access some of these services.
And if you made a mobile app that would bypass them, people would need to use VPNs.
In fact, most people don't want to use VPN.
So, as long as that is the situation, then this will not reach mass usage.
So, I want to talk quickly about opportunity areas.
We want to enable access.
And I'm going to also go into the three ways that the hierarchy that we established, right?
Confident.
So, we often say that you should make products in the crypto space that avoid having trust.
We challenge that and we would say try to leverage the trust that is already existing between people.
So, what if, for example, you had, these are product ideas that are provocations from the research that we have.
So, what if you had, for example, a program where there are digital banking ambassadors
that would onboard people onto using some digital money platforms and, you know, the most exciting
person in our community could tell the others, you know, this is how you would be able to load up money
and use these kinds of money systems.
In resilient category, we need to ensure consistent access to our systems even under bad infrastructure.
So, what if there's a way that we could enable offline mobile transfers even if it doesn't turn out to be
extremely censorship resistant or extremely double-spend resistant because people often transact
with people that they're going to transact with again.
So, it is in their best interest not to cheat the system in most cases.
Crypto bills, I saw there's some crypto bills flying around this conference as well.
So, this is like nice to see.
So, it's kind of the similar idea, kind of a bill where you can verify that, you know, the private key has
money and then you can just use it as if we're a bill of foreign currency.
And then open, we want the services to be accessible to everyone in practice and not just in theory.
So, if you had, for example, a USD wallet that you could cash in and out very easily.
That doesn't exist yet.
And USD wallet, it can be a stable coin, it can be, you know, it doesn't have to be crypto,
although we would very much prefer it if it were, right?
Money changer multipliers.
So, we notice that one of the things that people do to earn money in Venezuela is to be money changers,
to be able to exchange money from one system to another and they earn some money,
hopefully in the good currency.
So, what if we trained a lot of people to become more nodes in this network of money changing
and then we did it in a way that was safe for people to interact?
Universal point of sale system.
So, if there was a way for people to pay in the mechanism of payment that is required of them,
and for example, this guy that had to pay with Zell wouldn't have been in such a rush to find the way to pay
because there could be a way for him to convert, you know, if he had dollars in cash,
there could be a way, for example, to convert to other currencies.
And then, if we could have joined crypto accounts, if you have a family member that knows a little bit more about crypto
and is in Colombia, for example, you would need to send the money if you share an account
and you could load it up in one country and then you could use it in another,
and that could be interesting as well.
So, I want to quickly, because I don't have that much time, introduce a new crop of useful products that we've found
since we did this research, so Coinbase just released their light version of the wallet,
and give crypto is actually giving out crypto currency to people that need it,
and they're running some pilot programs, which is interesting.
There is a new framework for open source wallets that are running on all low versions of Android,
which was not, like, this didn't exist before, and this is like, now open source,
I'm going to present this in room D in a few minutes as well.
There's a company called Reserve that's actually allowing people to buy and sell dollars,
digital dollars, and they have a stable coin, so they are allowing people to do that
with their bank accounts in Venezuela, and they have a very seamless and very easy to use application for that,
because it's great.
And then, there's a company called Value that's allowing people to send money from Colombia to Venezuela,
and they're solving a huge problem for the 1.5 million migrants that are in Colombia,
and perhaps they could integrate some of these ideas to, for example,
instead of sending the money to a bank account in Venezuela, they could send the money to a wallet,
and it would stay in dollars.
That would be super cool as well.
So some quick takeaways for builders.
I want us to focus on what is useful, because there's a lot of focus on what is usable,
and usability is a great, it's a great conversation to have the UX audits,
the design track, it's all cool, but I want us to focus on things that are actually very, very useful,
rather than just usable.
And then I would challenge the idea that we all need to work towards mass adoption,
and I would push us to go and work for products that some people really, really need,
and it's easier to focus in solving a smaller problem.
And I want us to think, where is money restricted?
Where are other places where we could conduct this research,
and we could get inspiring results and inspiring new products?
So thank you, these are our sponsors, and please follow us on Twitter.
[Applause]
